fields.description:
The red block indicating that a reviewer has completed a review is useful. Would be even more useful if there was an indicator of 'in progress'.

I would suggest a half-filled/diagonal red block if ANY file has the checkbox clicked or if the reviewer has submitted any comment on the review. Maybe even half orange if comments submitted but no checkbox depending on how much information you wanted to present in the graphic.
fields.summary: Add indicator on review list for reviewer status when they've partially completed a review

fields.description:
If you have a review with a mix of comments on both the diff and the full source, there is no good view that can be used during a "review discussion" meeting, or as a printout - to just show the relevant information.

What I'd like to see is a view of the review that would show each comment, and the lines it applies to, with X lines of context, but ONLY should those lines.

I'm fine with this view being read-only and not allowing insertion of new comments, although I believe it should allow you to respond to existing comments.
fields.summary: Add "Comment Summary" view that shows only contextual information around each comment, not whole source/file

fields.description: Right now, if you expand all to start reviewing and check off some files, then come back later - the "expand all" isn't useful since it also expands the files you've already reviewed. Please add a 'Expand All Unchecked' option to only expand the files that are not checked off as completed.
fields.summary: Add a "expand all unchecked" option to top of review screen

fields.description:
Currently, I review code backwards, process is generally:

Expand All
Scroll to bottom
Review from bottom up, clicking checkbox to mark as completed each time I finish a file

I know the checkbox is not required, but is useful for tracking.

Problem is - this backwards review is annoying and in some cases makes you miss stuff. If you go forwards though - you have to scroll back up to the top of the file to mark it done. If you skipped any, you have to be careful to find the top of the file. Adding a linked checkbox - or simple js link to set the checkbox would eliminate that need to scroll back up.
fields.summary: Would like a 'completed' checkbox at the END of the diff in addition to the beginning

fields.description:
The ability to move a project from one of their crucible servers to another (which houses its own crucible projects). 

A function similar to confluence export/import space would allow customers to easily do this
fields.summary: Be able to export the projects on one server and import them into another

fields.description: In the "change diff" drop down the dates are being displayed incorrectly --- see http://skitch.com/annabuttfield/s789/cr-fe-604
fields.summary: Changeset dates are wrong
Add xwork action that returns the text summary (for copying and pasting).
Add send summary button and form
Update summary template to include comments

fields.description:
Right now, if a review gets created and is draft, or is assigned to a moderator - only those particular users can do anything with that review. There doesn't appear to be any mechanism for an administrator (even with the new multi-admin functionality in 1.6) to either take ownership of that review or to alter it in place.

Current impacts: 

   can't clean up a whole bunch of left-around draft reviews without getting individual end users to clean them up
   if a review is assigned to a different moderator, no one else can take it over and manage it without that moderator passing it along
fields.summary: Allow administrators to alter review state/members/etc. for reviews assigned to a different moderator or created by another user
In comment search, allow searching on review author - so we can find all reviews made against a particular author's code

fields.description:
the text of email notifications should be linkified using the configured linkers. 

Generated from [https://support.atlassian.com/browse/FSH-1108]. Some customers would find it useful to customise comments (such as using regex substitutions) before they are sent to the user. 

For example to do something like Linkers in fisheye, attach links to certain codes. 

However currently the comments are formatted by our class CheckinCommentFormatter which is not customisable by our customers.
fields.summary: Apply FishEye's linkers to outbound notification messages

The Crucible REST API does not return useful errors when requests fail (either 200 if the request succeeds, or 500 in all other cases).

Improve error handling by return 404, 403 and 400 where appropriate.

N.B.
It would be good if all POST and DELETE calls that don't have a response body would return 204 (No Content), instead of 200 with an empty string. However, to avoid breaking existing REST clients, this is not part of this change.

fields.description:
ReviewService.updateComment() and .postComment() take both a PermId<CommentData> as well as a PermId<ReviewData> argument. The latter is redundant as the review is already part of the PermID of the CommentData.

In addition to being redundant, the PermId<ReviewData> is used to do the permission check. As a result, a client can supply a one of its own reviews to by-pass the permission check and then update somebody else's comments.
fields.summary: Updating general comments in the REST api has a permission flaw

fields.description:
See screenshot.

1) You have a project where anyone can be a reviewer (ie the allowedReviewer fields are blank)

2) You add a default reviewer. This automatically adds that person as an allowed reviewer.

3) Because the allowedReviwer fields are no longer blank, only that person is now allowed to be a reviewer.
That was not the desired change.

Solution:

a) Only add the new default reviewer to the allowed-reviewer list if both the allowed-reviewer lists are empty. (Also, do we check to see if the person is already an allowed reviewer?)

b) (stretch) show an interstitial div near the allowed-reviewers saying "Person X was also added as an allowed reviewer"

c) (stretch) don't add to allowed-reviewers if that person is already in one of the allowed-reviewer groups, and say so in the interstitial.
fields.summary: [admin] adding a "default reviewer" incorrectly adds an "allowed reviewer" in some cases

fields.description:
How do I use a specific change set number to add files to a review? 

When I am editing a review, and I click the "Manage files" tab, the most recent change lists containing files starting from the project's repository location are shown. I have a single repository definition ("P4-production"), with the "repository path" defined to the root of the depot ("//depot/"). Thus, the changeset selection page says, "Files in P4-production:/ " the changesets that are first presented are global, and not usually useful.

The list can be manipulated by time with the "Remove all revisions | « Earlier Changesets | later » " options, or filtered with "Author", "Branch", or "Tag" text boxes, but nothing allows me to navigate directly to a give changeset number ("change list" in Perforce).

If I navigate directly to a Changeset through Fisheye to a URL like "http://balius:18060/changelog/P4-production/?cs=66106", then there is no check-box to add the changeset to the review.

BTW, what is a "tag" in a Perforce-based Fisheye installation? Is it equivalent to a  P4 Label?
fields.summary: How to (easily) add specific changeset to a review

fields.description:
Apparently, Crucible cannot handle some of the patches created by Subversion. When trying to view the diff for some of the files I get the message:

> The reported problem was:
> AnnotatorTag
> 
> You are running release CR1.5.2 FE1.5.2 (build-299 2008-05-26), please report your release number when reporting bugs.

We found out that this only happens for files that have been renamed and modified, in this case Subversion creates a patch like:

{noformat}
Index: file.xml
===================================================================
--- file.xml	(revision 0)
+++ file.xml	(working copy)
@@ -13,7 +13,7 @@
   a
   b
   c
-  dd
+  d
   e
   f
   g
{noformat}

Note "(revision 0)" annotation here, that one is causing the problems. If that text isn't there or replaced by some valid revision number (if the file is only moved but not renamed) everything is fine. However, for "(revision 0)" Crucible doesn't seem to expect modifications to an existing file in the patch.
fields.summary: AnnotatorTag error: diffs for a file that has been moved cannot be shown

fields.description:
Hey guys,

When I create a new review there is some text below the 'Statement of Objectives' box which says...

"This review is in draft. Click the Start Review button to notify reviewers"

However, if I then choose a moderator who is not the creator and click 'Save' , the 'Start Review' button becomes a 'Send to Moderator' button but if I then open the review again the text under the 'Statement of Objectives' box still reads...

"This review is in draft. Click the Start Review button to notify reviewers"

Shouldn't this be something like...

"This review is in draft. Click the Send To Moderator button to notify the moderator that this review must be approved"

??

Thanks,

Mark

fields.description:

I'm in two minds, Confluence supports anonymous users both for page creation and commenting and it is a win (especially for demo instances). I'm not sure if it has as much utility in the real world for Crucible though.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce 

1) In Admin > Projects, Create crucible project with key CRU
2) Create a review under the CRU project 
3) Go into Admin > Projects and edit project CRU to set the key as CRUC
4) Create another review and somewhere in the title or description, add the text "CRU-1". 

When you save the review, the CRU-1 will be rendered as a link to the review, a link like [http://sol:8060/cru/CRU-1] however the project CRU no longer exists. 

This can cause issues for people who have Jira and Fisheye installed who have created a project under fisheye but later renamed it because it conflicts with the the project key in Jira. When they create reviews via Jira this automatically attaches JiraProjectKey-issuenumber to the title of the review. 

However if JiraProjectKey is the same as the Crucible project key (before it was changed to due to the conflict), rather than showing a link to jira, it shows a link to Crucible (to a non existant project within crucible). 

However if you have defined a [Linkers|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Linkers] in the fisheye, this will override the bad url. I.e. for the above go to 

Admin > Repository Defaults > Linkers > Add simple link
{noformat}
Regex:CRU-\d+
Href: http://jirahost:8080/browse/${0}
{noformat}

and this will ensure that CRU-1 actually points to Jira rather than to crucible non existent project.
fields.summary: Crucible automatically creates links to crucible projects if you define PROJECTKEY-number, however if you change the projectkey it still creates links

fields.description:
Our developers love Crucible, but when creating a code-review the files are restricted to the "Author" only.
This is confusing because the author was not the last to commit changes in the selected files, and when the moderator is trying to add the newer file versions it's filtered by author -- again not showing the latest revisions until you change the author to "any".

And when there is an existing comment on a file - then even the moderator can't include the "newer" revisions.

It's very frustrating for your users/moderators/developers.

Please make it more usable.

fields.description:
4. Setting up your Web Server/ [Configuring the FishEye Web Server|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Configuring+the+FishEye+Web+Server]:

Says "You can force the FishEye application to be hosted on a different 'context' or 'path' by specifying a value here." At first I could not tell where is "here"? But then I realised that is meant through the admin interface. But in my case, I could not get through the firewall to the server except through port 80. So I had a deadlock. Eventually I found a post that had an example of the jetty configuration.

4. Setting up your Web Server/ [Integrating with Other Web Servers|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Integrating+with+Other+Web+Servers]:

For this I'm not sure what is right. (I'm a developer not an admin.) What I ended up doing (again from a post) was:

  ProxyPass /fisheye http://localhost:8060/fisheye
  ProxyPassReverse /fisheye http://localhost:8060/fisheye

This (so far) seems to work. I don't know what ProxyPassReverse does.
fields.summary: Clarify Proxying FishEye Configuration Docs

Now I have added a second repository, my production server, and stopped the first. The first shows on the dashboard with a status of 'stopped', but the second does not show at all on the dashboard. In the admin page, they both appear, and the first has a status of 'Enabled: Stopping', and the second has a status of 'Enabled: Running'. They have been like this for serveral hours.

What is going on here?

fields.description:
The only way we're able to track the changes that have been made to a review is to watch all the notification emails that come out (and only if someone is subscribed, and only if they didn't delete them).

It would be a great improvement if a Crucible review were to have a tab that summarized changes made to it. Similar to Jira's "Change History" tab. As the review goes through different states, as people are added/removed as reviewers or other roles, as comments are added/updated, etc.
fields.summary: Add Jira-style change tracking tab

fields.description:
The default review screen only shows a single line for the objectives, and gives zero indication that more info is available. The "Plus" box is there regardless.

I attached a screen shot with what I mean - if you don't actually take the time to expand the objectives you're going to miss all this other stuff.

One fix would be to only show the + box if there is actually more info available. But this minor UI element is still going to get missed by people (I've noticed this on my team anyway). Why is this info hidden anyway? It seems much more reasonable to always show it and have the user choose to hide it.

-----

Suggestion: have the statement of objectives always visible and expanded. If the user chooses to hide it, ok, save that state in the db for future views, but the initial view should default to visible. Otherwise it's so easy for people to miss the objectives that were typed in.
fields.summary: "Statement of Objectives" UI gives no indication there is more info
